p.seg: Mencius had an audience with the King Huì of Liáng (i.e. Wèi).
The King said:
"Venerable Sir,
not considering one thousand lǐ to be too far you have come here,
surely you must have something wherewith to bring profit to my state!"
Mencius replied politely:
" Why must Your Majesty speak of 'profit'?
What I surely have [for you] is Goodness and Rectitude, and that is all.
If Your Majesty says:
'How can one bring profit to my state?'
then the dignitaries will say,
'How can one bring profit to our clan?'
and gentlemen as well as commoners will say,
'How can one bring profit to my person?'
and then those above and those below will get entangled in their quest for profit
and the state will get into danger.
In a state with ten thousand war chariots,
anyone assassinating its ruler (with any lasting success for himself),
would certainly be of a clan with thousand chariots.
In a state of one thousand chariots,
anyone assassinating its ruler
would certainly be of a clan with one hundred chariots.
One thousand out of ten
or one hundred out of a thousand
does not count as little.
If someone really places rectitude last and profit first,
he will not be satisfied unless he takes by force what is not his.
There never has been anyone who, being Good, abandoned his parents;
There never has been anyone who, being possesed of rectitude, put his sovereign last.
Your Majesty should surely speak of Goodness and rectitude
Why must you speak of profit.
Mencius had an audience with the King Huì of Liáng.
The King was standing by a pond,
looked around at the wild swans, wild geese and the milu deer
and he said:
"Presumably a worthy, too, enjoys these?"
Mencius answered politely:
"Indeed one has to be a worthy to (really) enjoy these things.
Those who are not worthy, even if they do have these, they will not enjoy them.
The Book of Songs say:
' He planned and began the Terrace of Supernatural Efficacy
He planned it and built it,
The people worked at it;
in few days they completed it.
He planned and began it without urging them to make speed,
but the ordinary people came like children (to help their father).
The King was in the Park of Supernatural Efficacy.
where the doe lay
The doe were sleek;
The white birds glistened.
The King was at the Spirit Pond.
Oh! It was full of leaping fish!'
King Wén used the labour of the people and built the terrace and the pond,
and the people were perfectly happy with this.
They called his terrace the 'Terrace of Supernatural Efficacy'
and called his pond the 'Pond of Supernatural Efficacy',
and they were delighted that he possessed his milu deer, his fish and his turtles.
The men of antiquity shared their joys with the people,
that is why they were able to enjoy their things.
Tāng's Oath says:
(The people say:) 'This Sun (i.e. Jie), when will it perish?
We and you will die together.'
The people were relishing the prospect of dying together with him.
Tāng may have had his terrace and pond, his birds and beasts,
but could he have enjoyed them all by himself?"
King Huì of Liáng said:
"As for my approach to the state,
I exhaust all my energy for it and nothing more.
If there is disastrous famine in Hé Neì,
I move its people to Hé Dōng
and move the grain to Hé Nèi.
If there is disastrous famine in Hé Dōng,
I act correspondingly.
When one investigates the administration of the neighbouring countries,
there is no one there who is as energetic as I.
Yet the population of the neighbouring countries is not getting any smaller (for that)
and my population is not increasing.
Why is this so?
Mencius replied politely:
"Your Majesty is fond of warfare,
allow me, please, to explain it using a battle (as example):
Bang bang, set the drums the armies into movement,
the armies already came into contact.
(The soldiers) fled throwing away armours and trailing the weapons.
Some of them stopped after one hundred paces,
some of them stopped after fifty paces.
If one hundred paces were mocked from the point of view of fifty paces,
what would it be like?
(The King) said:
That would unacceptable.
They just did not run hundred paces and that is all.
Such behaviour is also a case of running away.
(Mencius) said:
If you understand this properly,
so do not in any case expect that the population will be bigger than in the neighbouring states.
Do not go against the agricultural seasons and the grain will really be impossible to be eaten completely up.
If close-meshed nets will not enter the pools and ponds, fish and turtles will really be impossible to be eaten completely up.
If the axes enter hills and forests only at proper time, the timber will really be impossible to be used up.
If grain, fish and turtles would be impossible to be eaten completely up
and the timber would be impossible to be used up,
that would cause the people to take care about those who are alive and to mourn over those who are dead without hatred.
Nourishing the living and burying properly the dead without feeling resentment
that is the origin of the Way of the true King.
As for the homesteads of five mǒu in size, plant them with mulberry trees
and those who are fifty might actually wear silk.
As for the domestic animals like chickens, piglets, dogs and swine, one should not to miss their right time
and those who are seventy might actually eat meat.
As for the lots of one hundres mǒu, you must not deprive them of their proper time (for cultivation)
and families with several members might actually not suffer from famine.
Pay close attention to the teaching at the schools,
enlighten them on the moral principles of being filial and respectful towards elder brothers
then the grizzled do not walk the roads carrying things on their shoulders or heads.
That those who are above seventy wear silk and eat meat,
and the common (sun-tanned) people do not starve or freeze,
but that under these conditions one does not become a true king
this is something that has never ever happened.
The dogs and swine eat the food for men, but you are not willing to restrict yourself.
On the roads there are people dying from starvation and the corpses, but you are not willing to release (the grain)
When people are dying, then to say:
'That was not because of me, it was because of the (bad) season.'
How does this differ from killing somebody by stabing him and to say:
'That was not because of me, it was because of the weapon'.
If you never blame the season, Majesty,
then the people of the whole Empire will come to you."
King Huì od Liáng said:
" I would like to quietly receive the instructions.
Mencius replied:
"As for killing somebody with a stick or a sword,
do you have any mean for distinguishing between these?"
"I really have no way of distinguishing between them."
As for using the sword or political measures,
have you got any means how to distinguish it?
(The King) said: "I really have no way of distinguishing between them."
(Mencius) said:
There is fat meat in your kitchen
and there are well-fed horses in your stable,
the people have hungry appearance,
in the countryside there are dying from starvation and the corpses,
that really means to lead the beasts and to eat people.
When animals eat each other,
then the people find this deplorable.
When someone is 'father and mother' to the the people
but in carrying out the government fails to avoid leading the beasts to eat people,
how could this be part of being 'father and mother' of the people?
Zhòng Ní said:
'The first person to make burial figurines,
deserved, presumably, to be deprived of any offspring?'
It was because he used symbolically represented men.
What would it be like,
if he had caused these people to starve and to die?"
King Huì4 of Liáng said:
As for the state of Jìn,
under the Heaven there was none stronger than it.
That is, what you are, venerable Sir, aware of.
But since times came to me personally,
in the East I was defeated by Qí,
my eldest son died there.
In the West I lost the territory to Qín of size of seven hundred lǐ lenght and width,
in the South I was humiliated by the state of Chǔ.
I consider these a disgrace,
and I would like to clean it completely up on behalf of those who died.
What shall I do so that things will be all right.
Mencius replied politely:
As for the territory of a square with the side of one hundred lǐ,
it is possible to become the True King with it.
If Your Majesty will dispense benevolent reign to the people,
will be sparing in the use of physical punishments and fines
will reduce the taxes and levies,
(enable the people) to plough into depth and wield the hoe with ease,
The adults will in the spare time cultivate their filial and fraternal love, the loyality and trustworthiness,
being at home, they will thus serve their fathers and eldest brothers,
being outside, they will thus serve their seniors and superiors,
they will really be able to be ordered to produce sticks in order to strike against the firm armours and sharp weapons of Qin and Chu.
They are robbing their people of the proper time,
making the people to have no chance to plough and hoe
in order to nourish their parents.
The parents are freezing and starving
the brothers, wives and children become separated and scattered.
They are trapping and drawning their people
if you, Majesty, will set out and launch an expedition against them,
who would compete with you?
Therefore it is said:
' The good one has no enemies.'
I beg Your Majesty to be not in doubt about this."
Mencius had an audience with King Xiāng of Liáng.
When he came out,
he told the others:
When I saw him at a distance, he did not look like a lord of men,
When I approached him, I have not noticed anything to be revered at him.
Suddenly he asked:
"How to settle the Empire?"
I replied:
"(It can) be settled by unification"
"Who is able to unify it?"
I replied:
"That one who is not fond of killing the people is able to unify it"
"Who would be able to join him?"
I replied:
"In the Empire there will really be nobody who would not join him."
Your Majesty, you certainly know about those sprouts?
If there is a drought during the seventh and the eighth months,
the sprouts are becoming dry.
Then the Heaven makes the clouds to arise densely,
makes the rain to fall abundantly
and as for the sprouts, it makes them to get up vigorously again.
As for it's being like this,
who would be able to hinder it?
Now as for these shepherds of men under the Heaven,
there really has still not been such, who would be not fond of killing people.
If there where such, who would be not fond of killing people,
then all the people of the word would actually stretch their necks and look towards him.
It will be really so.
The people will turn to him,
just like water flowing downwards with a rush,
who will be able to stop it?
King Xuān of Qí asked:
"Is it possible to get to know something about the affairs of Duke Huán of Qí and Duke Wén of Jìn?
Mencius replied politely:
"As for the disciples of Zhòng Ní
there was nobody who would speak about the affairs od Huán ans Wén among them.
That is, why as for the later generations, there does not exist any account there
and I have never heard about them.
Since I have no means (to let you know something about them), then what about becoming a true King?
(The King) said:
"What virtue must there be,
that one could become the true King ?
(Mencius) said:
"If he would govern protecting the people,
there will be really nobody who could stop it."
(The King) said:
"Can somebody like myself protect the people???"
(Mencius) said:
"You can."
(The King) said:
"Whence are you so sure that I really can?"
(Mencius) said:
"I have heard the following from Hú Hé who said, that
you were sitting in the ceremonial hall
and there was somebody who draged along an ox and was passing the bottom of the hall.
You noticed it
and said:
'Where is the ox going?'
He replied:
'We are going to use it to smear a bell.'
You said:
'Let it go,
I can not bear his frightened resistance,
like being innocent and approaching the place of dead.
He replied:
'In this case shall we really abandon the smearing of the bell?'
You said:
'How would it be possible to abandon it?
Replace it with a sheep.'
I do not know whether it happened?"
The King said:
"It happened."
(Mencius) said:
"This mind is already sufficient to become the true King with.
All the people regarded you as being parsimonious,
but I know for sure that you could not bear it."
The King said:
"That is true,
there certainly were certain people among the masses (who thought that way).
The state of Qí may be poor,
but how could I be stingy with one ox?
Just because I could not bear that it was opposing
like being innocent and approaching the place of dead,
therefore I replaced it with a sheep.
(Mencius) said:
"Your Majesty should not be surprised that the people regarded you as being parsimonious.
You have replaced the big one with the small one,
how could they have understood it?
If you felt pained by the fact, that it was innocent and was approaching the place of dead,
then as for an ox and a sheep, what was there to choose between them?
The King laughed and said:
"Really, what was that for an idea??
As for me, it was not the case at all that I would have grudged the value of it and replaced it with the sheep.
It was so appropriate that the people have said about me that I was parsimonious!"
(Mencius) said:
"There was no harm (in acting like that),
that was exactly the way of benevolent behaviour.
You actually saw the ox and did not see the sheep.
As for the gentleman and his attitude to the animals,
having seen them alive,
he cannot bear seeing them dead.
Having heard their voices,
he cannot bear eating their meat.
Therefore 'The gentleman puts his kitchen as far as possible'.
The King was pleased and said:
"The Odes say as follows:
'The other man had something in mind,
but I (personally CH) surmised it.'
This describes you, Master.
Now it is I who have done it,
but when I thought back and sought for it,
I have not found my motives.
You, Master, spoke this
and there appeared a positive emotion in my mind.
What is the reason, why this mind conforms with being a true King?"
(Mencius) said:
"If there were somebody who would report to you, saying:
'My strength is sufficient to lift one hundred jūn,
but is not enough to lift one feather.
My keen eyesight is sufficient to see the tip of an autumn hair,
but I cannot see a carriot with firewood.'
would you then approve it as true?"
The King said:
"I would not."
"And now, if one's generousness is sufficient to reach the animals,
but the achievements do not reach the people,
how would you take it?
If it is correct, then the feather is not lifted,
because one did not use his strength upon it.
The cartload of firewood is not seen,
because one did not use his sight upon it.
The people has not been protected,
because one did not use his generousness upon it.
Therefore, the reason why you do not rule like a true King
is because of your not-acting,
not at all because of your incapability."
(The King) said:
"As for the image of somebody who does not act and somebody who is unable to,
by what means do you distinguish between them?"
(Mencius) said:
"(If the task is) to clasp Mount Tai under one's arm and to jump with it over the Northern Sea,
to tell other people:
'I cannot do it.'
this is really the case of incapability.
(If the task is) to break off a branch in favour of a superior,
to tell the people:
'I cannot do it',
this is the case of not-acting,
and not of incapability.
Therefore, the fact that you are not ruling like a King,
is not from the category of clasping Mountain Tai under arm and jumping across the Northern Sea,
the fact that you are not ruling like a King
is from the category of breaking off a branch.
If one treats the aged of his own family in a way they should be treated, and extends it to the aged of other people,
if one treats the young of his own family in a way they should be treated, and extends it to the young of other people,
the Empire can be rolled in one's palms.
The Odes say:
'He was a good example for his wife,
extended it to his brothers
and so he ruled over the clan and the state.'
It means, that you should raise this mind and apply it to others, nothing more. DISCUSS THIS!
Therefore, if one pushes forward his generousness, it is enough to protect the whole world.
If one does not push forward his gnerousness, he has no means to protect his wife and children.
As for the reasons why the men of ancient times greatly exceeded the others,
there is no other one, than
they were good at pushing forward of what they were, and that is all.
"And now, if one's generousness is sufficient to reach the animals,
but the achievements do not reach the people,
how would you take it?
If one weighs, only then he knows the weight.
If one measures, only then he knows the length.
The things are all like this,
but the mind counts as most (important).
I beg you, King, to measure it.
Or when you are mobilising the army,
endangering the freemen and officers,
arousing resentment among the feudal lords,
do you only then feel pleasure in your mind?
The King said:
"No,
How could I be pleased with such things?
I am about to seek for what I greatly desire."
(Mencius) said:
"Is it possible to get to learn about what you greatly desire? "
The King smiled and did not make any comment.
(Mencius) said:
"Is it because the fat and sweet things are not sufficient for your mouth (to eat)?
The light and warm things are not sufficient for your body (to dress)?
Or is it because the various colours are not sufficient for your eyes to watch?
The sounds and tones are not sufficient for your ears to listen?
The favourites are not worth ordering about in front of you?
All your subjects are sufficient to supply these things,
I wonder, are you (doing it) because of these??
(The King) said:
"No,
I am really not (acting so) because of these things."
(Mencius) said:
"In this case, what you greatly desire, can be known already."
You wish to open up the territory,
summon the states Qín and Chǔ,
rule the Central States
and pacify the Barbarians.
By acting like this to seek for such wishes
is just like to climb up a tree and to seek for fish.
The King said:
" Is it really so bad?"
(Mencius) said:
Maybe it is even worse.
As for climbing up a tree and seeking for fish,
maybe one will not catch the fish,
but there will be no future disaster.
By means of such acting
to seek for (fulfilment of) such a wish,
if you do it using the whole capacity of mind and energy,
afterwards there will certainly be an disaster.
(The King) said:
"Is it possible to learn about it?"
(Mencius) said:
"If the people of Zōu were fighting with the people of Chǔ,
then who do you think would win?
(The King) said:
"The people of Chǔ would win.
(Mencius) said:
"If it is true, then the small one certainly cannot oppose the big one,
the few certainly cannot oppose the many,
the week one certainly cannot oppose the strong one.
As for the areas in the world,
there are nine of those who are of one thousand lǐ sqare
and Qi all in all has one part of it.
As for subduing eight with one,
how to distinguish it from Zōu opposing Chǔ??
Apparently, we must return to it's roots.
Now, if you will execute the government deploying Goodness,
then it will make all those in the world who are engaged in public service to desire to stay at your court,
all those, who are engaged in agriculture to desire to plough in your countryside,
all the merchants to desire to store goods at your market places,
all the travelers to desire to go along your roads,
all those in the world, who want to blame their rulers
to desire to report their complaints to you.
As for it's being like this,
who will be able to hinder it?
The King said:
"I am stupid,
I cannot advance to this.
I hope that you would assist my intentions,
enlighten me in order to instruct me.
I may be slow,
but allow me, please, to try it."
(Mencius) said:
As for those who lacking constant material resources have constant minds,
only the freemen are able (of this).
As for the common people, on the other hand, if they have no constant suport,
they, accordingly, have no constant mind.
If they really have no constant mind,
then among unrestrainedness, depravity, wickedness, extravagance,
there will be nothing what they would not do, for sure.
When it happens that they have run into criminality,
then to punnish them consequently,
this is ensnaring and misleading the people.
When did it happen to be possible, that a benevolent man on the throne
ensnares the people?
Therefore, when the wise ruler controls the property of the people,
he must make them to have enough in order to serve their parents above,
to have enough in order to nourish their wives and children below,
so that they are always saturated in bumper years
and escape from death in bad years.
Only under these conditions they hasten towards goodness,
and that is, why the people would serve him with ease.
And now, you control the property of the people,
so that they have not enough to serve their parents above,
have not enough to nourish their wives and children below,
in bumper years they are always in troubles
and in bad years they do not escape from death.
Thus they only save themselves from death and are afraid of deficite,
what leisure do they have to cultivate the rites and righteousness??
If you want to make it,
then why not turn to its roots?
As for the homesteads of five mǒu in size, plant them with mulberry trees
and those who are fifty might actually wear silk.
As for the domestic animals like chickens, piglets, dogs and swine, one should not to miss their right time
and those who are seventy might actually eat meat.
As for the lots of one hundres mǒu, you must not deprive them of their proper time (for cultivation)
and families with eight members might actually not suffer from famine.
Pay close attention to the teaching at the schools,
enlighten them on the moral principles of being filial and respectful towards elder brothers
then the grizzled do not walk the roads carrying things on their shoulders or heads.
that the old people wear silk and eat meat,
and the common people do not starve or freeze,
but that under these conditions one does not become a true king
this is something that has never ever happened.
Zhuāng Bào went to see Mencius and said:
"I was received by the King
and the King told me, that he was fond of music.
I not quite know how to reply."
(Zhuāng Bào) went on to ask:
"What do you think about being fond of music?
Mencius said:
"If the King's love of music were strong enough,
then the state of Qí, I think, would be near-perfect!!!!!!"
Another day,
he was received by the King and asked:
"You have formely told Zhuāng Zǐ, that you were fond of music,
did it happen?"
The King changed in expression of his face and said:
"I am really not able to love the music of the former kings,
I just love the popular music and that is all."
(Mencius) said:
"If your love of music were strong enough,
then Qí would be, I suppose, near-perfect!!
The today's music is basically the same as the ancient music."
(The King) asked:
"Is it possible to get to know about it?"
(Mencius) said:
"To enjoy music alone
or to enjoy music with others,
what of these is more delightful?"
The King said:
"It is better with the others."
(Mencius) asked:
To enjoy music together with few
or to enjoy music together with many,
which of these is the more delightful?"
(The King) said:
"It is better with many."
Allow me to explain the enjoyment for you.
Supposing, you would perform music here,
the people would hear the sounds of your bells and drums,
the tones of the pipes and flutes,
they all would with aching heads and knitted noses speak to one another, saying:
'When our King likes making music,
then why does he make us to sink into such extremities?
The fathers and sons do not see each other,
the brothers, wives and children are getting separated and scattered.'
Supposing, you were hunting here,
the people would hear the sounds of your chariots and horses,
see the beauty of your banners,
they all would with aching heads and knitted noses tell one another, saying:
'When our King likes hunting,
then why does he make us to sink into such extremities?
The fathers and sons do not see each other,
the brothers, wives and children are getting separated and scattered.'
There would be no other (reason) for it,
if would be because you would not enjoy youself together with the people.
Now, supposing, that you would perform music here,
the people would hear the sounds of your bells and drums,
the tones of pipes and flutes,
they all would get a delighted expression and they would ask one another:
'Our King has probably no illness?
Otherwise how could he have musical performance?'
Now, supposing, you would be hunting here,
the people would hear the sounds of your horses and chariots,
see the beauty of the banners,
they all would get a delighted expression and would ask one another:
'Our King has probably no illness?
(Otherwise) how could he be hunting?'
There would be no other (reason )for it,
it would be because you would enjoy yourself together with the people.
If you could enjoy youself together with the people, you would really become the true King."
King Xuān of Qí asked:
"The park of King Wén was seventy kilometers sqare,
is that true?"
Mencius replied politely:
"It exists in the records."
(The King) went on asking:
"So big it was?"
(Mencius) said:
"The people still considered it being small."
The King went on asking:
"My park is fourty miles square,
but the people still consider it being too big,
why is it so?"
(Mencius) said:
"The park of King Wén was seventy miles square,
those who gathered hay and small firewood used to go there
those who hunted for pheasants and hares used to go there.
He shared it together with the people
and that the people considered it being small,
was it not all right?"
When I came for the first time to the border,
I inquired about the major prohibitions in the state,
and only then I dared to enter.
I got to know, that within the area between the outskirts of the capital and the border check-point
there is a park of forty miles square.
The one who would kill a milu-deer there,
would commit a crime as if he had killed a man.
Thus these forty miles square are becomming a trap in the middle of the state.
That the people considers it being too big, is it not all right?"
The King Xuān of Qí asked:
"As for cultivating good relations with the neighbouring states, is there any method (of doing it)?
Mencius answered politely:
"Yes, there is.
Only a benevolent man is able with a great state to serve a small one.
Therefore Tāng served Gě,
King Wén served the Kūn tribe.
Only a wise man is able with a small state to serve a great one.
Therefore King Tài served the Xūnyù,
Gōujiàn served Wú.
The one who with a big state serves a small one, is somebody who delights in Heaven.
The one who with a small state serves a big one, is somebody who is in awe of Heaven.
The one who delights in Heaven retains the whole world,
The one who is in awe of Heaven retains his state.
The Odes say:
'(Zhōu Chéng Wáng) was in awe of the autority of Heaven,
and so he retained it.'
The King said:
"Oh, how great is this saying!
But I have a weak point,
I am fond of valour."
(Mencius) replied politely:
"I beg you, King, do not be fond of small valour.
Now, to take up a sword, look fiercely and ask:
'How does he dare to match himself with me?'
This is the valour of a commoner,
it is something good for opposing one man.
I beg you to extend it.
The Odes say:
'The King blazed in anger,
Then he arranged his troops,
In order to stop the invasion against Jǔ,
To increase the good fortune of Zhōu,
In response to (the hopes) of the Empire.'
This was the valour of King Wén.
The King Wén once bursted in anger
and brought to peace the people of the whole Empire.
The Documents say:
"The Heaven produced the inferior people,
created a ruler for them,
created a teacher for them,
and ordered, that they just have to assist the God to love them.
In the whole world, if somebody guilty or somebody is innocent, it is solely matter of our responsibility.
In the Empire, how can somebody dare to override their will?"
If there was only one man acting violently in the Empire,
King Wǔ considered this a disgrace.
That was the valour of King Wǔ.
And King Wǔ also only once bursted in anger
and brought to peace the people of the whole Empire.
Supposing, that you would also only once burst in anger
and bring to peace the people of the whole Empire,
then the people will be afraid only of that, that you are not fond of valour.
King Xuān of Qí received Mencius in the Snow Palace.
The King asked:
"Do also the talented and worthy have such kind of enjoyment?"
Mencius replied politely:
"Yes, they have.
When the people cannot get it (this enjoyment),
they start to criticise their superiors.
If they do not get it and condemn their superiors,
they are wrong.
If somebody counts as the superior of the people and does not enjoy himself together with the people,
he is also wrong.
If one delights in the people joys,
then the people will also delight in one's joys.
If one is worried by the worries of the people,
then the people will be worried by one's worries.
That, when one's delight has the whole world as it's scope
and one's worry has the whole world as its scope
somebody should fail to become a true king
that has never ever happened.
Once, Duke Jǐng of Qí asked Yànzǐ:
'I wish to visit Zhuǎnfù and Cháowǔ,
to follow the sea and move southwards,
arrive at Lángyé.
What kind of training must I have in order to be able to match the visits of the Former Kings?'
Yànzǐ replied politely:
'Oh, how excellent is this question!
When the Emperor visited the Feudal Lords, it was called xúnshòu;
Xúnshòu means to inspect (xún) what he controls (shǒu).
When the Feudal Lords were called for audience by the Emperor, it was called shùzhí;
Shùzhí means to report (shù) on what they were in charge of (zhí).
There was nothing what would not be a part of public service.
In spring, (the Emperor) inspected the ploughing and helped those who had not enough (for sowing),
In autumn he inspected harvesting and supported those who had any shortages.
The Xià proverb says:
'If our Emperor were not travelling in spring,
how could we have any rest?
If our King were not traveling in autumn ,
how could we have any aid?'
Each time he travels in spring and in autumn
he becomes an example for the Feudal Lords.
But today it is not that case.
(The Emperor) moves with the whole army and the provisions are consumed.
As for the starving, he refuses to feed them,
as for the exhausted, he refuses to give them rest.
(The superiors) are looking askance and are slandering one another
and the people then start to commit wickedness.
(The Emperor) discards the Mandate of Heaven and oppresses the people,
beverages and food are flowing like water.
(The Emperor's) drifting down the river, travelling in boats pulled against the river stream, excessive hunting and intemperance,
become matters of concern for the Feudal lords.
To follow the stream and move downwards and to forget about returning
is called "drifting";
to follow the stream and move upwards and to forget about returning
is called "pulling";
to pursue the animals without having enough
is called "excessive hunting"
to enjoy alcohol without having enough
is called "intemperance".
The former Kings had no excessive enjoyments (like traveling up and down the stream for a long time)
and wicked activities (like unrestrained hunting and alcoholism),
think of what are you doing.
The Duke Jǐng was pleased,
he made big scale preparations in the capital,
then he went out and dwelled in the outskirts.
And then he for the first time established the practice of issuing the grain and helping those who were needy.
He called the Grand Musician and said:
"Compose for me a piece of music on the theme of Lord and subjects pleasing one another."
Probably, the Zhǐ Sháo and Jué Sháo were these pieces.
Their text runs as follows:
'What is there wrong in pleasing the Lord?'
By 'pleasing the Lord'
is meant 'loving the Lord'.
King Xuān of Qí asked:
"Everybody tells me to destroy the Bright Hall,
Should I destroy it or should I not?"
Mencius answered politely:
"As for that Bright Hall, it used to be the Hall of the True Kings.
If you wish to execute the Royal Government,
you should by no means destroy it."
The King went on asking:
"Is it possible to learn something about the Royal government?"
(Mencius) replied:
"In the past, when King Wén ruled over Qí,
the farmers worked on the 1/9 system,
the officers enjoyed hereditary emoluments
at the borders and market places there were controls but no taxing,
there were no prohibitions respecting fish-traps,
criminals were not punished together with their family members.
Being old and wifeless is called 'widower',
being old and husbandless is called 'widow',
being old and childless is called 'solitary',
being young and fatherless is called 'orphan'.
These four kinds of people
are the most destitute in the world and they have nobody to complain to.
Whenever King Wén executed the government and promoted Benevolence,
he inevitably put these four kinds on the first place.
The Odes say:
'The rich people are acceptable,
but sympathise with those poor and solitary.'
The King said:
"Oh, how excellent is this saying!"
(Mencius) said:
Since you consider it as excellent,
then why are you not practising it?"
The King said:
I have a week point,
I am fond of luxury goods.
(Mencius) replied politely:
In ancient times, Duke Liú used to be fond of money.
The Odes say:
'Then he gathered and stored,
He packed the provisions
in bags and sacks.
The people lived in peace and thus he became famous.
The bows and arrows were laid out,
ansd as well the shields, halberds, and axes
and only then he began the march.'
Therefore, when those, who stayed at home, had full granaries,
and those, who went on march had their sacks wrapped
only then they could begin the march.
If you are fond of the goods,
but share the fondness with the people,
how does it interfere with becomming the true King?"
The King said:
"I hav a weak point,
I am fond of women."
(Mencius) said:
In ancient times King Tài was fond of women,
he loved his consort.
The Odes say:
Gǔ Gōng Dàn Fǔ early in the morning was driving his horses
along the bank of the Western river, he arived to the bottom of Mount Qí,
and then together with lady Jiāng he started to look for a dwelling.
At that time,
at home there were no unmarried women of marriable age
and abroad there were no bachelors of marriageable age.
If you are fond of female beauty,
but will share these joys with the people,
in relation to becoming a king, what problems does this make?"
Mencius addressed King Xuān of Qí, saying:
Supposing amoung your subjects there was such one, who entrusted his wife and children to his friend
and went to Chu travelling,
but when he came back,
(his friend) had allowed his wife and children to freeze and to starve.
What should he do with him?
King said:
"Break with him"
(Mencius) went on asking:
If the Master of the Gentlemen was unable to control the freemen properly,
then what should be done about it?"
King said:
"Dismiss him."
(Mencius) went on asking:
If within the four borders there is disorder,
then what should be done about it?"
The King turned to his attendants and spoke of other matters.
Mencius came for audience to King Xuān of Qí and said:
"What I call 'old-established state'
does by no means refer to having tall trees,
but refers to having hereditary officers.
You have no longer intimate officers.
As for those, whom you appointed in the past,
today you do not know whether they will go away."
King asked:
"By what means do I recognize if somebody is untalented in order to dismiss him?"
(Mencius) said:
"The ruler of a state appoints the talented and worthy only if he has no other alternative.
He is about to make the low ones to overstep the honourable ones,
the distant ones to overstep the intimate ones.
May he not wary?
If all the attendants say, that someone is talented and worthy,
it is still not possible.
If all the Grand officers say, that someone is talented and worthy,
it is still not possible.
If all the people in the capital say, that someone is talented and worthy,
only then check him.
If you find the talent and worthiness at him,
only then employ him.
If all the attendants say, that somebody is unsuitable,
you should not follow them.
If all the Grand officers say, that somebody is unsuitable,
you should not follow them.
If all the people in the capital say, that somebody is unsuitable,
only then check him;
if you find something unsuitable at him,
only then remove him.
If all your attendants say, that somebody should be killed,
do not follow them;
If all the Grand officers say, that somebody should be killed,
do not follow them;
If all the people of the capital say, that somebody should be killed,
only then check him;
If you find a reason why he should be killed at him,
only then kill him.
That is, why it is said 'the people of the capital killed him'.
If the situation will be like this,
only then you may count as 'father and mother' of the people.
King Xuān of Qí asked:
"Tāng banished Jié
and King Wǔ killed Zhòu,
is that true?"
Mencius replied politely:
"It exists in records."
(King) went on asking:
"If the subject assassinates his sovereign,
is it acceptable?"
(Mencius) said:
"He who outrages Goodness,
is called 'robber'.
He who outrages Rectitude,
is called 'villain'.
A man who is a robber and villain
is called 'outcast'
I have indeed hearth about punnishing outcast Zhòu,
I have never hearth about assassinating a ruler.
Mencius addressed King Xuān of Qí, saying:
"When you are building a large house,
then you have to order the Chief Carpenter to search for big pieces of wood.
When the Chief Carpenter has found big peaces of wood,
then you will become glad
and will consider him as being capable of fulfilling his duties.
When a craftsman chops them and makes them smaller,
then you will become angry,
and consider him as being not up to his duties.
Of course, one has since his childhood learned something,
and when he becomes adult, he wants to practise it,
but if you say:
'Now put aside what you have learned and follow me'
then what is it like?
Suppose, that there were a piece of unpolished jade here.
Even if it might cost ten thousand yì,
you have to order the jade-cutter to cut and polish it.
When it comes to making order in a state,
then to say:
'Now put aside what you have learned and follow me',
how to distinguish it from instructing the jade-cutter how to cut jade??"
The men of Qí attacked Yān and defeated it.
King Xuān asked:
"Some are telling me not to annex it,
some are telling me to annex it.
Being state of ten thousand chariots to attack a state of ten thousand chariots
and manage to defeat it in fifty days,
human abilities do not reach so far.
If we do not annex it, there will be surely a disaster produced by Heaven.
What about annexing it?
Mencius replied politely:
"If you annex it and the people of Yān will be glad,
then annex it.
Among the men of antiquity there were such who did it,
King Wu belongs to them.
If you annex it and the people of Yān will be unhappy,
then do not annex it.
Among the men of antiquity there were such who did it,
King Wén belongs to them.
When (Qí), as a state of ten thousand chariots attacks a state of ten thousand chariots,
and (its people ) with baskets of food and pots of rice soup welcomes your army,
is there any other reason than this?
It is because they are escaping from water and fire.
If the water becomes even deeper,
and if the fire becomes even hotter,
they will surely make a revolution, and that is all."
The men of Qí attacked Yān
and annexed it.
The Feudal Lords were about to make plans in order to rescue Yān.
King Xuān asked:
"Among the Feudal Lords there are many of those, who plan to attack me,
how to deal with them?"
Mencius replied politely:
I have hearth of those, who with seventy miles square gained the government over the whole Empire,
Tāng belongs to them.
I have never hearth of anybody, who would on the grounds of one thousand miles square fear the others.
The Documents say:
When Tāng set out for his military campaign,
he began with Gě.
Everyone started to consider him as trustworthy.
When he turned to east and set out for march,
the western barbarians complained.
When he turned to the south and set out for march,
the northern barbarians complained
and asked:
'Why does he put us last?'
The people placed their hopes in him
as if one watches for clouds and rainbow during the great drought.
Those, who were going to market did not stop,
those, who worked in fields did not change.
He punished the rulers and consoled the people,
like when the timely rain is falling.
The people became very delighted.
The Documents say:
'We are waiting for our lord,
when the lord comes we will surely be revived.'
And now, the state of Yān was oppressing its people,
you set out and chastised it,
the people believe, that you really will rescue them from the middle of water and fire,
with baskets of food and pots of rice soup welcomed your army.
If you kill their fathers and elder brothers,
enslave their children and younger brothers,
destroy their temple of the ancestors,
move away their precious bronze vessels,
how could this be acceptable?
The whole world was anyway scared about the fact, that Qí was powerful.
Supposing, that it in addition manages to double its territory,
but will not practise benevolent government,
then these conditions will set the armies of the whole world into movement.
If you quickly issue an order
to release their old men and small children,
and to retain their precious vessels,
if you discuss things with the people of Yān,
establish a ruler and afterwards leave it,
then they still may be managed to be stopped.
Zōu and Lǔ clashed.
Duke Mù asked:
"Of my officials there were thirty three who died,
but from the ordinary people nobody died for them.
If I execute them,
then they cannot be entirely executed.
If I do not punish them,
then how to deal appropriately with the fact, that they were watching resentfully how their superiors were dying and did not rescue them?
Mencius replied politely:
"In calamitous years and years of famine,
among your people, those old and week ones who were lying in ditches and valleys,
and those strong ones who became scattered and went to the four directions, were almost one thousand.
But your granaries were full
and treasuries stored,
and of the officials nobody has informed you about the situation.
That was because the superiors were neglecting the inferiors and were cruel to them.
Zēng Zǐ said:
'Beware it, beware it!
What proceeds from you,
is something, what will return to you again.'
Now, the people have only now got the opportunity to return it, haven't they?
You should not blame them.
If you will practise a benevolent government,
then indeed the people will love their superiors
and die for their leaders.
Duke Wén of Téng asked:
"Téng is a small state,
lies between Qí and Chǔ.
Should I serve Qí
or should I serve Chǔ?
Mencius replied politely:
"This advice is really not something, what I am able to grasp.
But if you insist,
then there is one point here (to say).
If you dig those moats,
build those walls,
defend them with the people,
risk your death and the people will refuse to leave,
then this really may be done.
Duke Wén of Téng asked:
"The men of Qí intend to fortify Xuē,
I am greatly scared.
What should I do about it?"
Mencuis replied politely:
"In ancient times King Tài dwelled in Bīn,
the people of Dí tribe encroached upon its territory,
he left and went to the bottom of mount Qí to settle there.
If was not the case that he had selected it and made this choice,
it was because he had no other alternative.
If one really shows excellence in action,
among one's descendents of the next generations there will invariably be true kings.
A gentleman, when starting an enterprise, leaves behind a tradition,
in order to make it possible to be continued.
But as far as the accomplishment of the intended result is concerned,
that depends on Heaven.
What are you supposed to do about them?
Try your best in doing good deeds and that is all."
Duke Wén of Téng asked:
"Téng is a small state.
If it will spend all its energy in order to serve big states,
then it will not be able to keep away from them.
What should I do about that?"
Mencius replied politely:
"In ancient times, King Tài dwelled in Bīn,
the people of Dí tribe encroached upon its territory.
He served them with skins and silks,
but was not able to get rid of them.
He served them with dogs and horses,
but was not able to get rid of them.
He served them with pearls and jade,
but was not able to get rid of them.
Thereupon he assembled his elders and announced to them:
'What the Dí tribes want, is our land.
I have heard this:
A gentleman does not with the thing, by means of which he nourishes the others, inflict harm on the others.
My friends, why should you be troubled about having no lord?
I for my part am intent to leave this place.'
He left Bīn, crossed mount Liáng,
built a city at the foot of mount Qí and settled there.
The people of Bīn said:
'He is a good man,
he should not be lost.'
They followed him as if they were rallying to a marketplace.
Another alternative says:
'As for a hereditary holding,
it is not something one can achieve by oneself.
Risk your death, but do not leave it.'
Please, my lord, make a choice between these two alternatives.
Duke Píng of Lǔ was about to go out.
One of the favourites, a certain Zāng Cāng asked for an audience and said:
"Other days, when you were going out,
you have certainly informed the officer in charge where you were going.
Now the chariot is already yoked,
but the officer still does not know where you are about to go,
so I dared to ask for an audience.
The Duke said:
"I am going to see Mencius."
(Zāng Cāng) said:
Oh, what is the reason that you are lowering yourself by making your first move towards a commoner?
Do you consider him as worthy?
Rites and Rectitude are arising from the worthy men,
but Mencius' second funeral (that of his mother) surpassed the first funeral (that of his father).
You must not be received by him."
The Duke said:
" I agree."
Yuè Zhèngzǐ entered for an audience and asked:
"Why did you not go to see Mèng Kē?"
(The Duke) said:
Somebody has said to me:
'Mencius' second funeral surpassed the first funeral.'
That is, why I did not go there to see him."
(Yuèzhèng Zǐ) asked:
What is, that you are calling by 'surpassing'?
Was the former one like (that of) freemen and the latter one like (that of) grand officials,
during the former one, did he use three tripods and during the latter one five tripods?
(The duke) said:
"No.
I meant by that the beauty of the coffins and burial clothes."
(Yuèzhèng Zǐ) said:
This is not what is called 'surpassing',
it was because his material conditions were different.
Yuèzhèng Zǐ visited Mencius and said:
I have told about you to the ruler,
the ruler was about to come and see you,
but among the favourites there was a certain Zāng Cāng, who dissuaded the ruler.
That is, why the ruler did not come in the end.
(Mencius) said:
If one acts, there is something that made one act,
if one stops, there is something, what made him to stop.
Acting and non-acting is not something, what one is capable of by himself.
That I have not met the ruler of Lu,
was because of the Heaven.
As for this fellow of the Zāng clan,
how could he had made me not to meet (the ruler)?
Gōngsūn Chǒu asked:
"If you, teacher, gained political influence in Qí,
could the achievements of Guǎn Zhòng and Yàn Zǐ be expected again?
Mencius said:
"You are really a native of Qí,
you just know Guǎn Zhòng, Yàn Zǐ and that is all.
Somebody asked Zēng Xī:
'As for you and Zǐ Lù, which one is the more talented and worthy?'
Zēng Xī said with embarrassment:
'He was somebody, whom my deceased father admired with respect. '
Then he went on asking:
'Then, as for you and Guǎn Zhòng, which one is the more talented and worthy?'
Zēng Xī became very angry and said:
'Why are you comparing me with Guǎn Zhòng?
Guǎn Zhòng gained the confidence of the ruler so exclusively,
he was practicing the government of the state for such a long time,
but his achievements were so insignificant.
How do you dare to compare me with such person?' "
(Mencius) added:
"Guǎn Zhòng was somebody, whom Zēng Xī would not perform,
and you think, that I would like to do it?"
(Gōngsūn Chǒu) said:
"Guǎn Zhòng made his ruler to become a hegemon,
Yàn Zǐ made his ruler to illustrious.
Are Guǎn Zhòng and Yàn Zǐ nonetheless not worth of being equalled in action?"
(Mencius) said:
"To become a true King with Qí
is not harder than to turn over one's hand."
(Gōngsūn Chǒu) said:
If it is true,
then my confusion has become even deeper.
Even with the kind of virtue like that of King Wén,
who has died after having lived until the age of one hundred years,
nonetheless (the virtue) still failed to permeate the whole world.
King Wǔ and Duke of Zhōu had succeeded him,
and only then it greatly prevailed.
If you are now saying, that to become a true King is so very easy,
then King Wén is not worth of being emulated as an example?
(Mencius) said:
"How can King Wén be matched?
From Tāng to Wǔdīng
a worthy and sage ruler appeared for six or seven times.
The Empire was rallying to Yīn already for a long time.
If something lasts for a long time, it is hard to be changed.
Wǔdīng summoned the Feudal lords
and governed over the Empire as if he had rolled it on his palm.
Zhòu was removed in time from Wǔdīng not too far yet.
Of the inhereted habits of their ancient ruling house, of the descended manners and good government there was still something what had survived.
In addition, he had Wēi Zǐ, Wēi Zhòng, prince Bì Gān, Jī Zǐ, Jiāo Gé,
they all were talented and worthy men,
who together assisted him.
That is why it was only after a long time that he had lost the Empire.
There was really no foot of land which would not be his ownship,
of the whole people there was really nobody who would not be his subject.
but King Wén started from one hundred miles square.
That is why it was difficult.
The people of Qí have a saying as follows:
'You may have intellect,
but it is better to make use of circumstances.
You may have a hoe,
but it is better to wait the right time.'
At present time, however, it is very easy.
When the Xià, Yīn and Zhōu started to dominate,
the territory of none of them ever exceeded one thousand miles square,
but Qí has already the requisite territory.
When the cocks were crowing and the dogs barking, they could hear each other,
and (their voices) reached all the four borders,
but Qí has already the requisite population.
(Even if Qí's) territory will be not further extended,
and the population will not become more abundant,
(If the King of Qí) will rule by practising benevolent government,
nobody would be able to stop it.
Moreover, of the intervals where a true King has not appeared,
there has never been a (more distant>) longer one than at this time.
Of the instances when people suffered from tyrannical government,
there has never been a worse one than at this time.
The hungry ones are easily to be provided with food,
the thirsty ones are easily to be provided with drink.
Confucius said:
'When the virtue spreads,
it is faster transmit orders by setting up postal stations.'
At present time,
if in a state with ten thousands war chariots one would practise benevolent government,
the people would appreciate it
as if they had been released from hanging by the heels.
Therefore, if one would employ only a half of a man of antiquity for service,
in one's achievements one would certainly exceed him twice.
It is only at this time that this is true.
Gōngsūn Chǒu asked:
"If you were holding the post of the Chief minister of Qí,
had a chance to put the Way into practice here,
even if (the King of Qí) thank to this became a hegemon or a true King, it would be not surprising.
If it were so, would you it cause stiring in your mind or not?
Mencius answered:
"No,
Since the age of forty I do not let my mind to stir."
(Gōngsūn Chǒu) said:
"If it is true,
then you surpass Mèng Bēn greatly."
(Mencius) said:
"That is not difficult.
Gào Zǐ at earlier age than me did not allow his mind to stir."
(Gōngsūn Chǒu) went on asking:
"Is there any method how not to allow one's mind to stir?"
(Mencius) said:
"Yes, there is.
As for (the way by which) Běigōng Yǒu cultivated his courage,
he never flinched because of his skin has been wounded,
he never turned his eyes aside.
In his reflection, he believed, that if his single hair has been bent by somebody,
it was as if somebody has beaten him at the marketplace or at the court.
He did not accept (any insult) from a commoner with coarse clothes,
and as well he did not accept (any insult) from a ruler with ten thousand war chariots.
He looked upon stabbing a ruler with ten thousand war chariots
like upon stabbing a fellow with coarse clothes.
He never had respect for Feudal lords,
if any bad words reached him,
he certainly returned them back.
As for the valour which was cultivated by Mèng Shīshè:
He used to say:
'I am looking upon not conquering and conguering in the same way.
If one measures the enemy and only then moves forward,
if calculates with victory and only then joins the battle,
this is somebody who would fear the entire military power of a state.
Of course I am not able to arrange, that I will surely win!
I am able never to be scared and that is all.'
Mèng Shīshě resembles Zēng Zǐ,
Běigōng Zǐ resembles Zǐ Xià.
As for the valour of these two gentlemen,
I do not quite know which of them is more preferable,
but Mèng Shīshè takes care of what is essencial.
Once, Zēng Zǐ addressed Zǐ Xiāng and said:
'Are you fond of valour?
I have once heard about supreme valour from the Master:
If I inspect myself and if I (find that I) am not in the right,
then even if there is only a common fellow,
will I not fear him?
If I inspect myself and if I (find that I) am in the right,
even if there is ten milion of people, I will go there.'
When Mèng Shīshè takes care of his fighting spirit,
yet he does not take care of the essence as well as Zēng Zǐ does."
(Gōngsūn Chǒu) went on asking:
"I venture to ask, whether
as for your (way of) not allowing your mind to stir
it is possible to learn something about?"
"Gào Zǐ says:
'What you fail to express in words,
do not seek in your mind for it.
What you cannot find in your mind,
do not seek in your physical energy for it.'
'What you cannot find in your mind,
do not seek in your physical energy for it',
is acceptable.
'What you cannot put in words,
do not seek in your mind for it',
is not acceptable.
In fact, the will is the commander over the physical energy
and the physical energy is that what fills the body.
The will is of the greatest importance here,
the physical energy is subordinate to it.
That is why it is said:
'One should stick to one's aspirations
and one should never let one's vital energies emerge into the open.'
"Since you have already said, 'the will is the most important here
and the physical energy is subordinate to it',
and you also said,
'hold firmly your will
and do not let your physical energy come out',
what is the point here?"
(Mencius) said:
"When the will concentrates, it sets the physical energy into motion,
but when the physical energy concentrates, it also sets the aspirations into motion."
As for those who by nature are hurrying and scurrying,
it is the matter of this kind of physical energy,
which ("relativischer Anschluss") in turn sets into motion (=affects, stirs) their minds.
I venture to ask, in which point are you stronger (than Gào Zǐ)?
(Mencius) said:
"I have, for my part, insight into words;
I good at cultivating my 'flood-like energy'."
I venture to ask, what does 'flood-like energy' refer to?
(Mencius) said:
"It is hard to explain.
This, being an energy,
is the biggest and the firmest one,
If you nourish it with moral strightness and do not cause any harm to it,
then it will fill the space between Heaven and Earth.
This, being an energy,
accompanies the Rectitude and the Way,
if they are lacking, it declines.
Is is something, what arises from accumulated rectitude,
in no case it is obtained when rectitude is occasionally manifested.
Whenever in course one's acting one feels dissatisfaction in his mind,
it collapses.
That is, why I say:
'Gào Zǐ never understood Rectitude',
because he regards it as external.
You must make your effort on it,
but you should not consider it being the target (of your efforts).
You should never forget about it in your mind,
but do not help it growing.
Do not be like that man of Sòng:
Among the men of od Sòng there was one, who was grieving that his seedling did not grow and therefore he was pulling them up.
full of exhaustion he returned home
